name: Kepler-176
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-176 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-176 is a star with 0.785 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.89 times its radius. It is located 1746.24 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-176 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-176 b

Kepler-176 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-176.

The mass of Kepler-176 b is 2.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-176 b is 1.43 that of Earth. At 2.29 Earth masses, Kepler-176 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-176 c

Kepler-176 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.76 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-176.

The mass of Kepler-176 c is 9.54 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-176 c is 2.6 that of Earth. At 9.54 Earth masses, Kepler-176 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-176 d

Kepler-176 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 25.75 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-176.

The mass of Kepler-176 d is 8.77 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-176 d is 2.51 that of Earth. At 8.77 Earth masses, Kepler-176 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-176, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
